column6: Waste directed to disposal
column7: NAB directed 36% of its waste to landfill in 2023.

column6: Non-compliance with environmental laws and regulations
New suppliers that were screened using environmental criteria
column13: The Group Supplier Sustainability Principles set out an expectation that suppliers will comply with all relevant local and national laws and regulations, provide transparent and public reporting on their ESG risks and have a process in place to provide timely disclosure to NAB of material ESG matters concerning their organisation.
column20: Group Supplier Sustainability Principles, regulation, ESG risk

column6: Negative environmental impacts in the supply chain and actions taken
column13: In 2023, NAB reviewed and refreshed the ESG risk assessment component of its Third-Party Risk Management Module, part of its enterprise risk management tool. It supports the ongoing management of supplier-related risks, including ESG risk.
column20: Third-Party Risk Management Module, ESG risk assessment, enterprise risk management tool

column6: New employee hires and employee turnover
Benefits provided to full-time employees that are not provided to temporary or part-time employees
column7: NAB was recognised for the second year as #3 in the 2023 LinkedIn "Top Companies to grow your career" in Australia. NAB also ranked #4 on GradAustralia's Top 100 Graduate Employers and #1 in the Banking & Finance industry.

column6: Parental leave
column13: This year, NAB strengthened its parental leave offering by providing equal leave to both parents by removing the distinction between primary and secondary carers. NAB also increased the number of weeks paid parental leave to 16 weeks upon the birth of a child and for adoption, foster and kinship arrangements for children under 16 years of age, with additional flexibility as to when the leave can be taken.
column20: Parental leave, parent, primary carer, secondary carer

column6: Parental leave
column13: In 2023, NAB introduced gender affirmation leave of up to 12 months, consisting of 4 weeks paid leave and the remainder unpaid. Colleagues who take steps to affirm their gender have the entitlement to build a gender affirmation plan alongside their people leader and a support person to help ensure a positive experience in affirming gender at work.
column20: Gender affirmation leave, paid leave, gender affirmation plan

column6: Minimum notice periods regarding operational changes
Occupation health and safety management system
column13: Through NAB's Employee Assistance Program, counselling services remain available to all colleagues, their families, and NAB customers. Customer utilisation of this service has increased during the year, and NAB expects to see this continue due to challenges in the external environment, including cost of living pressures.
column20: Employee Assistance Program, customer utilisation, cost of living

column6: Hazard identification, risk assessment, and incident investigation
column13: NAB has a robust program to support colleagues and customers in managing the impacts of natural disasters through counselling, leave options and emergency grants where the need arises. The introduction of an extra five days of leave, You Leave, in 2023 has led to a greater uptake of annual and long service leave this year.
column20: Service leave, natural disaster, emergency grant

column6: Occupational health services
column13: NAB implemented a refreshed well-being strategic framework in 2023 under the 'Right Culture' pillar of its Colleague Strategy. The focus has shifted towards initiatives that promote thriving whilst supporting colleagues with their recovery and safe return to work following work or non-work-related injury or illness. This service remains a priority, delivered through NAB's team of allied health professionals, which also includes assisting colleagues who have experienced domestic and family violence, ensuring that they have access to leave and specialist support services.
column20: Well-being strategic framework, Colleague Strategy, injury, illness

column6: Worker participation, consultation, and communication on occupational health and safety
column7: NAB's Heartbeat surveys have seen incremental improvements in the well-being score during the year, from 74 in February 2023 to 77 as of the July 2023 survey.

column6: Worker training on occupational health and safety
column13: NAB builds leader capability through communications and campaigns, the People Leader Fundamentals online program, webinars, and new tools to help manage team workload and well-being.
column20: People Leader Fundamentals, leader capability, well-being

column6: Promotion of worker health
column7: While NAB scaled back its COVID-19 response in line with changing Government requirements, unwell colleagues must stay home to prevent illness transmission.

column6: Prevention and mitigation of occupational health and safety impacts directly linked by business relationships
column13: As part of NAB's hybrid working model, most colleagues (excluding those in branches) can work flexibly, expecting to work from an NAB location (such as an NAB office) at least two days per week. NAB's hybrid approach includes tools and resources to support hybrid practices, in-person events, and greater face-to-face collaboration and social connection opportunities.
column20: Hybrid approach, hybrid working model, social connection

column6: Workers covered by an occupational health and safety management system
column13: NAB's focus has shifted towards initiatives that promote thriving whilst supporting colleagues' recovery and safe return to work following work or non-work-related injury or illness. This service remains a priority, delivered through a team of allied health professionals, which also includes assisting colleagues who have experienced domestic and family violence, ensuring that they have access to leave and specialist support services.
column20: Specialist support service, safe return to work, injury, illness

column6: Work-related injuries
column7: NAB's LTIFR in 2023 was 0.39 in Australia.

column6: Work-related ill health
column7: NAB's absenteeism rate in Australia in 2023 was 7.74.

column6: Average hours of training per year per employee
column7: NAB's average training hours in 2023 was 28 hours per employee.

column6: Programs for upgrading employee skills and transition assistance programs
column13: NAB's Career Qualified in Banking (CQiB) program continues to build colleagues' professionalism. NAB aims to have Australia's most qualified bankers to help build better customer relationships. In partnership with the Financial Services Institute of Australasia (FINSIA), NAB has enrolled more than 20,000 colleagues across the program's life. More than 14,500 colleagues have successfully graduated from the program, up from 8,000 in 2022.
column20: Career Qualified in Banking (CQiB) program, professionalism, banker

column6: Programs for upgrading employee skills and transition assistance programs
column13: NAB's investment in leaders continues through Distinctive Leadership Ã¢ÂÂ the approach to leadership for everyone at NAB. 92% of people leaders have completed Distinctive Leadership training workshops Ã¢ÂÂ an increase from 69% in 2022. In 2023, the Distinctive Leadership experience was extended to all colleagues (not just people leaders) through digital learning modules.
column20: Distinctive Leadership, leader, training workshop

column6: Programs for upgrading employee skills and transition assistance programs
column13: NAB redesigned its Home Lending Fundamentals program, a secured lender accreditation program focused on skills broader than home lending, including customer conversation practice, time to practice on tools and greater alignment with working methods.
column20: Home Lending Fundamentals program, lender accreditation, customer conversation practice

column6: Programs for upgrading employee skills and transition assistance programs
column13: NAB offers technical learning pathways, accreditations and core regulatory training to build capabilities in green and sustainable finance, cloud computing, engineering and product ownership. In 2023, this included investments in NAB's cloud skills training program, Climate training for bankers, NAB Cloud Guild, and deployment of the Technology Academy in Australia and Vietnam to build a pipeline of digital skills.
column20: Climate training for bankers, sustainable finance, cloud skill training

column6: Percentage of employees receiving regular performance and career development reviews
column7: The Chief Risk Officers provide oversight, challenge and independent input into NAB's performance review process.

column6: Diversity of governance bodies and employees
column13: NAB's I&D Policy requires the Board to set measurable objectives for achieving inclusion and diversity, which, together with progress on the framework, is assessed and reported on at least annually. The ELT has direct accountability for the execution of the framework. All leaders at NAB have I&D goals included in their annual performance plan. The Board and the ELT aim for a workforce reflective of the broader community and a reputation that attracts and retains the best talent.
column20: I&D Policy, inclusion, diversity

column6: Diversity of governance bodies and employees
column13: The NABility Employee Resource Group, a voluntary group of colleagues with disability, carers of people with disability and allies, has used internal and external storytelling to celebrate the role and valuable contributions that colleagues with disability have at NAB. The Group also delivered internal events to encourage disability pride and reduce ableism.
column20: NABility, disability, ableism

column6: Ratio of basic salary and remuneration of women to men
column13: NAB takes specific steps to ensure all colleagues are paid equally for the same role, including undertaking pay equity reviews as part of its annual performance and remuneration process. This analysis compares pay for similar roles and seeks to account for legitimate factors driving differences in pay (e.g. seniority, expertise, experience, and performance). Following this recent review in 2023, NAB made positive adjustments to the end-of-year remuneration decisions of more than 400 colleagues.
column20: Pay equity review, remuneration process, remuneration decision

column6: Incidents of discrimination and corrective actions taken
column13: NAB's Cultural Inclusion Employee Resource Group aspires to promote an inclusive workplace where cultural diversity is celebrated, to increase diverse representation in senior leadership roles, and to harness the power of cultural inclusion. The Group provides a forum for colleagues to celebrate many cultural dates of significance and works passionately to help culturally diverse colleagues advance their careers at NAB.
column20: Cultural Inclusion Employee Resource Group, inclusive workplace, cultural diversity

column6: Incidents of discrimination and corrective actions taken
column13: NAB has zero tolerance for sexual harassment and works to fulfil its duty to prevent sexual harassment and discrimination. In response to the Respect@Work legislative changes, a detailed gap analysis has been completed using the Australian Human Rights Commission's Good Practice Indicators Framework to ensure NAB has clear outcomes and measures on leadership, culture, training, risk management, support, reporting, monitoring and evaluation.
column20: Gap analysis, sexual harassment, discrimination

column6: Incidents of discrimination and corrective actions taken
column13: Additional actions to strengthen leadership responsibility, bystander interaction, training and risk management are underway. A psychosocial risk working Group meets quarterly to identify trends and issues and proactively address risk indicators of sexual harassment and other forms of unlawful discrimination, harassment and bullying.
column20: Psychosocial working group, leadership responsibility, risk management

column4: Freedom of Association and Collective Bargaining
column6: Operations and suppliers in which the right to freedom of association and collective bargaining may be at risk
column13: NAB seeks to proactively identify, assess and address human rights risks and impacts that may arise in business relationships with customers and suppliers, as outlined in its Human Rights Due Diligence process. It includes issues such as poor labour practices, modern slavery, Free, Prior and Informed Consent, and improper land acquisition.
column20: Human Rights Due Diligence, human rights risk, modern slavery
